data.title: Add a postLaunchTask attribute to launch.json
data.body: launch.json needs a postLaunchTask attribute similar to preLaunchTask.  It would be very helpful for launching any other processes needed to debug the application, like a web browser or other client application.

data.title: Reactivate windows nsfw tests
tmux on Windows doesn't respond to mouse events in terminal

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (63def6eb989d62f23d3711ace0f795ce9f23551d, 2017-06-28T05:16:57.588Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16226
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.3
prettier-vscode|esb|0.20.0
macros|ged|1.2.0
vscode-settings-cycler|hoo|1.0.1
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.6
shell-launcher|Tyr|0.1.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Configure VSCode terminal to use a WSL Bash shell on Windows. (`"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\WINDOWS\\sysnative\\bash.exe"`)
2. Open a terminal and run `tmux` (with `set -g mouse on` in `~/.tmux.conf`).
3. Output enough text to the terminal to overflow the window.
4. Attempt to scroll with the mouse.
5. Open a new panel (`Ctrl+B, %`).
6. Attempt to resize the panels with the mouse.
7. Attempt to focus each panel by clicking within one and then the other with the mouse.


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Steps 4, 6, and 7 all fail but _do_ work in the normal "Bash on Ubuntu on Windows" terminal outside of VSCode. This is also a problem in 1.13.1. I'd hoped #9958 would fix the problem, but it didn't. (Assuming it made it into the insider build for today?)

1. Get a link to display in the terminal bigger than one line
2. Ctrl+click it
3. It will only take the first line of the link

data.title: Open Multiroot workspace from command line
data.body:
If you pass multiple folders to `code`, we currently open multiple instances of VSCode:

```bash
code ~/server ~/client-ios
```

I believe we should add an option that opens all the passed in folders as roots in a workspace. This could either be the default behavior or controlled with a flag:

```bash
code --multiroot ~/server ~/client-ios
```

data.title: files.watcherExclude should be case insensitive on windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Testing #29478 but not a regression from 1.14

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. In a workspace, create a file called `ABC.txt` and open it
2. Exclude the file from the file watcher using a lowercase name `abc.txt`:

```json
   "files.watcherExclude": {
        "**/abc.txt": true
    }
```

3. Open the file in an external program  and edit it

**Expected**
Edits to `ABC.txt` are not reflected

**Actually**
Edits to `ABC.txt` are still reflected. This is not a regression 1.13 and happens when using both the old and new watchers

data.title: Watcher does not pick up changes in mounted network drive directory on windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Testing #28945 but this is not a regression

- VSCode Version: 1.14-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Mount a network drive. For example, go to `This PC` ->  `map network drive` and mount `https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/teams/DD_OTP/Documents/Java and Open Tools/Node/test` onto the `Z:` drive
1. Open this mounted folder in vscode
2. Open a file
3. In an external program, edit the file and save it

**Bug**
Changes to the file as not reflected in vscode

Tested using both the old a new file watchers. Neither seems to work

data.title: onDidCloseTextDocument fired twice for every document close
Multi-line LF-ending files paste from Code into PowerShell in reverse order
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows NT 10.0.14393.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set file to use LF line endings (does not occur with CRLF line endings)
2. Copy multiple lines from VSCode or Notepad -- this seems to be the same symptom reported by RobBiddle in Feb: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2205#issuecomment-277069894
3. Paste into Powershell v 5.1.14393.1198 where text lines have reversed order. 
Workaround: Contents print correctly with Get-Clipboard, which paste correctly after being copied from Powershell.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Format on paste should only do something when it pastes a new line
Emmet - easy to get error from selectNextItem
data.body:
If I put the cursor not on an html tag, like on whitespace, then I get an error notification that selectNextItem failed. We might want to swallow the error and just not do anything in that case.

But also there are some places where it seems like it should still work, like on the first character of (some) tags.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/323878/27661556-9384f3f4-5c0f-11e7-8c58-e25d7113683a.png)

data.title: Ripgrep fails to respect `when` clause to ignore search results.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 
Version 1.14.0-insider
Commit 63def6eb989d62f23d3711ace0f795ce9f23551d
Date 2017-06-28T05:11:17.011Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04.2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a `test.js` and `test.ts` file containing string `foo`.
2. Add `    "search.exclude": {
        "**/*.js":
        {
            "when": "$(basename).ts"
        }
    }` to settings.
3. Search workspace for string `foo`.
4. Notice results from test.js appear in search results.

5. Add `"search.useRipgrep": false` to settings
6. Notice results from `test.js` ignored correctly.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Unusable due to slow startup.  Fresh install win 32, no extensions, startup > 10  Minutes!
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13

- OS Version: Windows 7 32 bit

NOTE: I also have Visual studio 2012 installed on this computer and it's running in a virtual machine.
Visual studio 2012 opens within seconds, there is almost no noticeable delay running in this fast virtual machine.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Download and install VS code on Windows 7 32 bit
2. Runs fast first time after installation and opens up to the welcome screen
3. Close, go to command prompt and run again Code --disable-extensions
4. Nothing happens, open task manager and it's showing Code.exe and cpu is pegged at 99% 
5. Start a stopwatch, wait 10 minutes cpu varies between 99% and rarely dips to 97%.
6. Give up.  No visible Code editor onscreen anywhere, just the task manager process is the only evidence it's doing anything; stop the process.

I left it to start one time as I had to go out, came back about half an hour later and it was opened so at some point it *does* actually complete the startup but I have no idea how long it took.

Same thing happens when I run it without disabling extensions by the way and I've tried it through several reboots uninstalls etc.  

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

I've used Code on Linux previously (64bit Debian in virtual machine on same host computer) and it runs very fast and is very useful, however I wanted to consolidate all my work to my windows dev machine and ran into this issue.

This is a clean install, I'm guessing my difference from others may be that I have vs 2012 installed already?  Only thing I can think of that might have some possibility of interfering with it.

Testing #29479

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (63def6eb989d62f23d3711ace0f795ce9f23551d, 2017-06-28T05:07:46.148Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.0.0
- Extensions: 


**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open integrated terminal find widget and type in some text
2. Try using the standard system select all keyboard shortcut (<kbd>cmd</kbd><kbd>a</kbd> on mac)


**Bug**
The contents of the terminal are selected instead of the contents of the find widget input box. This is different than how the editor find widget works

data.title: Extensions: Disable always, but enable only on certain workspaces
data.body:
If I set the extension to "Disable always", e.g. C/C++ extension which I usually don't need, then I can't enable it selectively on those few projects where I need it.

This would be perfect way to make VSCode do less useless things, I could disable many extensions always but enable them only on *certain workspaces*.

It should store the extensions which are selectively enabled to workspace settings file, this way it could be stored in the version control and *suggested for anyone who opens the workspace*.

Tested with 1.14.0-insiders.

Here is the GUI in C/C++ extension if it's disabled always, the Enable > Workspace is then grayed out:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64731/27658038-4cffe82e-5c57-11e7-83e7-d296e9e74606.png)

data.title: Terminal find does not update on subsequent presses of enter
data.body:
Testing #29479

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Open integrated terminal
2. Run `ls`
3. Search for the start of a term such as `tsf` in the vscode project directory. Press enter
4. Enter more of the search term, such as `tsfmt`. Press enter again.

**Bug**
Highlight of the found text is not updated


![jun-28-2017 12-55-28](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12821956/27657325-27eed852-5c01-11e7-93bd-f8ea80c19f34.gif)
